questions.text: Tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas affects which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
• Parts of pancreas: Head, Neck, Body and Tail.
  • The head has three borders-superior, inferior and right lateral; two surfaces-anterior and posterior.
  • One process, projects from the lower and left part of the head towards left is called the uncinate process.
  • Uncinate process: It is related anteriorly to the superior mesenteric vessels, and posteriorly to the aorta.
  • Tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas affects the superior mesenteric vessels.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume 2, 9th Edition, Page No. 350, 353

questions.text: Tattoo is not visible on autopsy. But the presence of tattoo was informed by relative. What is the next site to check?
questions.solution:
Revealing Latent Tattoo Marks

Latent tattoo marks are faded marks and they can be visualized by:

  1. Use of ultraviolet light.
  2. Infrared photography.
  3. Rubbing the part and examining under magnifying glass.
  4. If tattoo marks are obscured by decomposition, they can be visualized by treating the area with 3% H2O2.
  5. Tattoo marks can also be developed by treating the skin with 0.5% caustic potash.
  6. Faint or faded tattoo marks can be made out on histological examination of regional lymph nodes. The lymph nodes near a tattoo mark show deposit of pigment used for tattooing.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No. 67, 68

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of C.L.D. with ascites presents with abdominal pain and tenderness. Ascitic tap shows presence of 600pmn cells/cu.mm. Which of the following is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
• Abdominal pain and tenderness in a C.L.D. patient with ascites suggests SBP, if the ascitic fluid analysis shows PMNC>250/mm3.
  • SBP is also seen in ascites due to nephrotic syndrome, heart failure, acute hepatitis. Rare in malignant ascites.
  • SBP is characterized by the culture of a single organism. SBP is due to enteric pathogens - E coli, Klebsiella, Streptococcus, Enterococci.
  • TB ascites will have ascitic fluid lymphocytosis. AFB smear is 0.3% positive. In patients without cirrhosis an elevated ADA has > 90% sensitivity.
  • Chylous ascites are seen with milky ascitic fluid with TG>200 mg/dl. It is due to lymphatic disruption occurring with trauma, cirrhosis, tumor, TB or certain congenital abnormalities.
  • Black Fluid-Pancreatic necrosis or metastatic melanoma
  • Presence of multiple pathogens in ascitic fluid without PMN elevation suggests bowel perforation with paracentesis needle.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page number: 323-324.

questions.text: A child reports to you at 1 year of age. He has received DPT for 6 weeks. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
• If a dose of DPT, IPV, Hib, PCV, Hep A, Hep B, HPV, MMR or Varicella vaccine is missed, subsequent immunization should be given at the next visit as if the usual interval had elapsed.

Reference: IAP guidebook of immunization, 2018, pg. 87

questions.text: A migrant labor presented with complains of urethral discharge one week after unprotected sexual intercourse, accompanied with painful micturition. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Gonorrhoea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae,
  • Gonorrhoea involves incubation period 3-10 days
  • The most common site of gonococcal infection in men is the urethra (80%), rectum (40%), and pharynx (10%-20%). If symptoms develop, they often manifest within 10 days of infection.
  • Major symptoms include copious purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, and perimeatal erythema
  • Treatment for uncomplicated urogenital, anorectal, and pharyngeal gonococcal infection is ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) given in a single dose.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 30, page 30.3

questions.text: A family consuming predominantly of polished rice would present with which of the following deficiencies? Match the vitamin deficiency with the investigation used to detect the deficiency:
questions.solution:
A family consuming predominantly polished rice likely to have thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

Option A: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. But here likely vitamin deficiency is thiamine.

Option B: Xanthurenic acid is excreted in vitamin B6 deficiency.

The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro.

Option C: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Not transketolase (used in thiamine deficiency).

Option D: Thiamine nutritional status can be assessed by erythrocyte transketolase activation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, CH 44, Pg 534

questions.text: Ribbon candy appearance on immunofluorescence is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Bullous pemphigoid is another distinctive acquired blistering disorder with an autoimmune basis.
  • Blistering in bullous pemphigoid is triggered by the linear deposition of autoreactive IgG antibodies and complement in the epidermal basement membrane.
  • Reactivity also occurs in the basement membrane attachment plaques (hemidesmosomes), where most bullous pemphigoid antigen (most commonly type XVII collagen) is located. The proteins that are recognized by the autoantibodies have structural roles in dermoepidermal adhesion. IgG autoantibodies to hemidesmosome components fix complement and cause tissue injury by recruiting neutrophils and eosinophils.
  • Deposition of IgG antibody (detected by direct immunofluorescence) in the subepidermal basement membrane (epidermis is on the left side of the fluorescent band).

Reference: Robbins, 10th ed, Pg 898

choices.text: Children in same community with ALL getting exposed to chemicals
Children in same community without ALL

questions.text: Many children from a particular community coming to a hospital were detected as having ALL. The hospital said that it was due to a chemical in the water of that community. If a case control study has to be done to find whether that chemical and ALL are associated, children having ALL are taken as cases, then what will be taken as controls?
questions.solution:
CASE CONTROL STUDY

  • Case control studies, often called "retrospective studies" are a common first approach to test causal hypothesis. The case control method has three distinct features:
    1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
    2. The study proceeds backwards from effect to cause; and
    3. It uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an inference.
  • By definition, a case control study involves two populations-cases and controls.

Basic steps: There are four basic steps in conducting a case control study:

  1. Selection of cases and controls
  2. Matching
  3. Measurement of exposure, and
  4. Analysis and interpretation.

SELECTION OF CASES AND CONTROLS

  • The first step is to identify a suitable group of cases and a group of controls.

SELECTION OF CASES

Definition of a case:

  1. DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA: The diagnostic criteria of the disease and the stage of disease, if any (e.g., breast cancer Stage I) to be included in the study must be specified before the study is undertaken. Once the diagnostic criteria are established, they should not be altered or changed till the study is over.
  2. ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA: The second criterion is that of eligibility. A criterion customarily employed is the requirement that only newly diagnosed (incident) cases within a specified period of time are eligible than old cases or cases in advanced stages of the disease (prevalent cases).

Sources of cases: The cases may be drawn from hospitals, or general population.

SELECTION OF CONTROLS

  • The controls must be free from the disease under study. They must be as similar to the cases as possible, except for the absence of the disease under study.
  • As a rule, a comparison group is identified before a study is done, comprising of persons who have not been exposed to the disease or some other factor whose influence is being studied.
  • Sources of controls: The possible sources from which controls may be selected include hospitals, relatives, neighbor's and general population.
    1. HOSPITAL CONTROLS: The controls may be selected from the same hospital as the cases, but with different illness other than the study disease. For example, if we are going to study cancer cervix patients, the control group may comprise patients with cancer breast, cancer of the digestive tract, or patients with non-cancerous lesions and other patients.
    2. RELATIVES: The controls may also be taken up from relatives (spouses and siblings). Sibling controls are unsuitable where genetic conditions are under study.
  • NEIGHBOURHOOD CONTROLS: The controls may be drawn from persons living in the same locality as cases, persons working in the same factory or children attending the same school.
  • GENERAL POPULATION: Population controls can be obtained from defined geographic areas, by taking a random sample of individuals free of the study disease. We must use great care in the selection of controls to be certain that they accurately reflect the population that is free of the disease of interest.

MATCHING

  • Matching is defined as the process by which we select controls in such a way that they are similar to cases with regard to certain pertinent selected variables (e.g., age) which are known to influence the outcome of disease and which, if not adequately matched for comparability, could distort or confound the results.
  • A "confounding factor" is defined as one which is associated both with exposure and disease, and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. More specifically a "confounding factor" is one that, although associated with "exposure" under investigation, is itself, independently of any such association, a "risk factor" for the disease.
  • This "confounding" effect of age can be neutralized by matching so that both the groups have an equal proportion of each age group.

MEASUREMENT OF EXPOSURE

  • Definitions and criteria about exposure (or variables which may be of etiological importance) are just as important as those used to define cases and controls. Information about exposure should be obtained in precisely the same manner both for cases and controls.
  • This may be obtained by interviews, by questionnaires or by studying past records of cases such as hospital records, employment records, etc.

ANALYSIS

  • The final step is analysis, to find out
    • Exposure rates among cases and controls to suspected factor
    • Estimation of disease risk associated with exposure (Odds ratio)

In this case, controls has to be without disease, i.e without ALL and should not be exposed to the risk factor i.e chemicals.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 79

questions.text: Familial HNPCC is due to defect in?
questions.solution:
Defects in DNA repair leads to the following diseases:

  1. Nucleotide excision repair: xeroderma pigmentosum. The exposed skin is dry and is extremely sensitive to UV rays
  2. Mismatch repair: HNPCC. Lynch syndrome. It is associated with colon cancer, more involving the proximal colon, <50 years of onset of age and predisposition to ovarian and uterine cancers. AD inheritance. Germline mutations lead to microsatellite instability in mismatch repair genes, involved in detection of nucleotide mismatch and slipped strand trinucleotide repeats.
  3. Homologous recombination repair factors: Covalent DNA cross links and double stranded DNA breaks are repaired through homologous recombination. Defects in these mechanisms lead to
    • Bloom's syndrome (AR. Mutation in helicase enzyme involved in homologous recombination),
    • Fanconi's syndrome (AR. More than a dozen homologous recombination genes are involved. Sensitivity to chemotherapeutic agents that cause DNA cross links),
    • Familial breast cancer genes (BRCA 1 and 2).
  4. Defects in DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase defects are extremely rare, due to the inherent exonuclease activity which allows the enzyme to insert the proper nucleotide in the complementary strand. If mutations occur in DNA polymerase, they are the heavily mutated cancers, they have numerous neoantigens and are most susceptible to immune checkpoint inhibitors. DNA polymerase mutation is seen in most of the endometrial and colonic carcinomas.
  5. Regulated genomic instability in B and T cells: T and B cells, during their development undergo gene rearrangement to allow for antigenic diversification. These include the RAG 1 and 2 genes in B and T cells and the activation induced cytosine deaminase (AID). AID induced DNA breaks are prone to translocation that lead to lymphoid neoplasms.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, page number: 3647-48; Robbins and Cotran's Pathologic basis of diseases, 10th edition, page number: 314-315

questions.text: A patient with asthma and hyperthyroidism, not on asthmatic medications, presented with anxiety, restlessness and BP of 180/110 mmHg, HR-120/min and ECG suggestive of atrial fibrillation. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Thyroid storm (thyrotoxic crisis):

  • This is an emergency due to decompensated hyperthyroidism.
  • Vigorous treatment with the following is indicated:
    • Nonselective β blockers (e.g. propranolol) are the most valuable measure.
  • Propylthiouracil reduces hormone synthesis as well as peripheral T4 to T3 conversion.
  • They are potent inhibitors of thyroid hormone released from thyroid, as well as peripheral T4 to T3 conversion.
    • Corticosteroids
    • Diltiazem 60-120 mg BD oral may be added if tachycardia is not controlled by propranolol alone, or when it is contraindicated.
  • Rehydration, anxiolytics, external cooling and appropriate antibiotics are the other measures.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 278

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Systemic (or peripheral) vascular resistance (SVR) decreases in pregnancy (-21%) due to smooth muscle relaxing effect of progesterone, NO, prostaglandins or ANP.
  • In spite of the large increase in cardiac output, the maternal BP (BP = CO × SVR) is decreased due to decrease in SVR.
  • There is overall decrease in diastolic blood pressure (BP) and mean arterial pressure (MAP) by 5-10 mm Hg. The decrease in maternal blood pressure parallels that of SVR.

Reference: William's Obstetrics, 25th edition, chapter 4, page no. 59; DC Dutta textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Chapter 5, Physiological changes in pregnancy, Page no. 60

questions.text: A 68 year male with cough, sputum and bronchial sounds. No confusion. RR 20/min, urea 38 mg/dl. BP 110/70mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
• The question depicts a patient with Pneumonia and is asking about the management, which depends on the severity.
  • The severity of pneumonia is calculated based on two scores-CURB 65 or the PSI.
  • The CURB-65 criteria include five variables:
    • confusion (C)
    • Blood urea Nitrogen >7 mmol/L (U)(>19 mg/dL)(Blood Urea of >40 mg/dl)
    • respiratory rate ≥30/min (R)
    • blood pressure - systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg (B)
    • an age of ≥65 years.
  • Patients with a score of 0 (a 30-day mortality rate of 1.5%) can be treated as outpatients.
  • With a score of 1 or 2, the patient should be hospitalized unless the score is entirely or in part attributable to an age of ≥65 years; in such cases, hospitalization may not be necessary.
  • Among patients with scores of ≥3, mortality rates are 22% overall; these patients may require ICU admission
  • Here the CURB 65 score is 1, but the score is attributable partly to his age. Hence he can be initially managed at home with antibiotics.
  • The other severity score is Pneumonia Severity Index.
  • To determine the PSI, points are given for 20 variables, including age, coexisting illness, and abnormal physical and laboratory findings. On the basis of the score, patients are assigned to one of five classes with these mortality rates: class 1, 0.1%; class 2, 0.6%; class 3, 2.8%; class 4, 8.2%; and class 5, 29.2%. Use of the PSI results in lower admission rates for class 1 and class 2 patients. Class 3 patients could ideally be admitted to an observation unit pending further decisions
  • Both CURB 65 and PSI scores are insufficient in determining the need for ICU admission. The presence of any of the factors given above which denotes severe CAP, should be admitted in ICU.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, page number: 1012

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with 6 months swelling moves with deglutition with strap muscle invasion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given image is typical histology slide of papillary thyroid cancer showing "orphan annie eye nuclei".

Moreover, the most common cancer found in thyroglossal cyst is papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, part 8, chapter 55, page 868.

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8pm and recorded blood glucose at 7am on the next day which was 180 mg/dl. What's the source of glucose in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dietary Glucose can provide glucose in blood for 4 to 6 hours.

The digestible dietary carbohydrates yield glucose, galactose and fructose that are transported to the liver via the hepatic portal vein. Galactose and fructose are readily converted to glucose in the liver.

Option B: Hepatic Gluconeogenesis provides a source of glucose 18 hours after fasting, when glycogen is depleted.

Option C: Liver glycogen functions as a reserve to maintain the blood glucose concentration in the fasting state. The liver concentration of glycogen is about 450 mmol/L glucose equivalents after a meal, falling to about 200 mmol/L after an overnight fast; after 12 to 18 hours of fasting, liver glycogen is almost totally depleted.

Option D: Muscle glycogen provides a readily available source of glucose-1-phosphate for glycolysis within the muscle itself.

Although muscle glycogen does not directly yield free glucose (because muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase), pyruvate formed by glycolysis in muscle can undergo transamination to alanine, which is exported from muscle and used for gluconeogenesis in the liver.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, CH 18, Pg 164

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Definition

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a condition that includes:

  1. Fulminating ulcer diathesis in the stomach, duodenum or atypical sites;
  2. Recurrent ulceration despite 'adequate' therapy; and
  3. Non-β islet cell tumors of the pancreas (gastrinoma).

Incidence

  • This is a rare disease affecting between 0.5 and 4 in a million.
  • Approximately 0.1% of patients with duodenal ulcers have evidence of ZES. Up to 20-25% of ZES is associated with MEN.

Pathology

  • In sporadic disease the tumors are mostly located in the duodenum (60-80%) and are small (<5 mm) and multiple.
  • In MEN 1, all tumors are in the duodenum.
  • The vast majority (approximately 90%) occur within the 'gastrinoma triangle' an area bounded by the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas medially, the junction of the second and third parts of the duodenum inferiorly and the junction of the cystic and common bile ducts superiorly.

Reference: Bailey and Love's short practice of surgery 28th edition, part 8, chapter 57, page no 907.

questions.text: 50-year-old male C/O fatigability persistent for one year. Mild anaemia massive splenomegaly. Hb 10 gm %, TLC of 120*10(3), platelet 500*10(3), Neutrophils 60, Basophil 4, Eosinophil 6, Lymph 15, Myeloblast 3. Rest were myelocytes and bands. M:E ratio of 18:1 Most specific further investigation
questions.solution:
• Applications of molecular genetic studies in acute leukaemia are shown in Box. Methods of molecular genetic analysis are Southern blot analysis, polymerase chain reaction-based techniques, and fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH).
  • Principle of Southern blot analysis is given elsewhere in this book. In a clonal disorder like acute leukaemia, cleaving of DNA by restriction enzyme will produce DNA fragments of the same size (since all the cells of a clone will have identical gene rearrangement), which can be detected by electrophoresis of DNA. In a non-malignant or reactive condition, due to the presence of multiple clones, fragments of DNA produced after restriction enzyme digestion are of different size. Immunoglobulin and T cell receptor gene rearrangements occur during B and T lymphocyte development respectively.
  • The rearrangement of immunoglobulin genes occurs in a specific sequence: µ heavy chain followed by kappa (κ) light chain that in turn is followed by lambda (λ) light chain. T gamma (Tγ) and T beta (Tβ) chain genes are rearranged earlier than T alpha (Tα) chain genes during T cell ontogeny.
  • These rearrangements are detected by Southern blot analysis using labelled cDNA probes. The usefulness of gene rearrangement studies in acute leukaemias as a lineage-specific marker is limited. This is because immunoglobulin heavy chain gene rearrangement, which occurs during B cell ontogeny, has also been observed in some cases of T-ALL and AML. Similarly T cell receptor gene rearrangements have been detected in some cases of B-ALL and AML.
  • However, light chain gene rearrangements occur only in B cells and are lineage specific. Identification of fusion genes (which are formed after translocations) such as the PML/RARα gene in AML M3, and BCR-ABL and TEL-AML1 fusion genes in ALL has prognostic and therapeutic importance. Algorithmic approach to diagnosis of acute leukaemias is shown in Figure:

Reference: Essentials of haematology, 2nd ed, Pg no. 239

questions.text: Instrument to measure Low wind velocity measurement and cooling power
questions.solution:
AIR TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT

Thermometers are instruments used for measuring temperature. Mercury thermometers are widely used, as mercury boils at a high temperature, has a regular expansion and its level can be easily seen. Alcohol thermometers are also used. Alcohol has the advantage of not solidifying even at the lowest known temperature. The essential conditions for the use of the thermometers are that:

  1. The air should have free access to the bulbs of the thermometers and
  2. The thermometer should be protected against radiant heat.

These conditions are fulfilled by mounting the thermometers on a special approved screen called the "Stevenson Screen" which is used in all the meteorological observatories in India.

  1. Dry bulb thermometer: This is an ordinary thermometer which measures the air temperature. For accurate readings, it is mounted on the 'Stevenson Screen', at a height of 1.20 to 1.80m above the ground level. The screen protects against radiant heat, direct sun and rain.
  2. Wet bulb thermometer: The wet bulb thermometer is precisely the same as the dry bulb thermometer except that the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth fed by water from a bottle through a wick. The evaporation of water from the muslin cloth lowers the temperature of the mercury. The wet bulb thermometer therefore shows a lower temperature reading than the dry bulb thermometer. The drier the air, the lower the wet bulb reading. If the wet and dry bulb thermometers record the same temperature, it means that the air is completely saturated with moisture, which is rare.
  3. Maximum thermometer: This is a mercury thermometer so designed that there is a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb. When the temperature rises, mercury expands; when the temperature falls, mercury cannot get back into the bulb. The end of the mercury thread at the distal end gives the maximum temperature reached. The thermometer is set each time by swinging briskly when the mercury retreats into the bulb.
  4. Minimum thermometer: The liquid inside the minimum thermometer is spirit, in which is immersed a dumb-bell shaped index. When the temperature falls, the spirit drags the index towards the bulb end; when the temperature rises, the spirit expands and runs past the index.
  5. Six's maximum and minimum thermometer: This is combination of the maximum and minimum thermometers. This instrument is not used in the Indian Meteorological Observatories.
  6. Globe thermometer: The globe thermometer is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings. The instrument consists of a hollow copper bulb 6 inches(15 cm) in diameter and is coated on the outside with mat black paint which absorbs the radiant heat from the surrounding objects. A specially calibrated mercury thermometer is inserted, with its bulb at the centre of the globe. The globe thermometer registers a higher temperature than the ordinary air temperature thermometer because it is affected both by the air temperature and radiant heat. The difference between the globe thermometer temperature and that of the ordinary dry bulb is a measure of the radiant heat. The globe thermometer is also influenced by the velocity of air movement. The standard globe instrument reaches equilibrium with its environment in 15 to 20minutes.
  7. Wet globe thermometer: It consists of a dial thermometer with the heat sensing portion enclosed by a blackened copper sphere that is completely covered with wet black cloth. The Wet Globe exchanges heat with the surroundings by conduction, convection, evaporation and radiation similar to the way a perspiring man does, so the equilibrium temperature of the globe provides a comprehensive measure of the cooling capacity of the work environment
  8. Silvered thermometer: The bright metallic surface reflects as much of the incident radiant heat as possible. This gives a more accurate reading of the air temperature.
  9. Kata thermometer: The Kata thermometer is an alcohol thermometer with a glass bulb 4cm long and 1.8cm in diameter. The readings on the stem are marked from 100 deg.F to 95 deg.F. Two instruments are used, the bulb of one is covered with a wet muslin cloth, the wet kata and the other dry kata. Before taking the readings, the bulbs are immersed in hot water to warm them slightly above 130 deg.F, when the alcohol rises into a small reservoir at the top of the instrument. The bulb of the dry Kata Is wiped dry. Then both the instruments are suspended in air at the point of observation. The time in seconds required for the spirit to fall from 100 deg. to 95 deg.F is noted with a stop watch. This is repeated at least 4 times. The first reading is discarded and the average of the last three is taken. The length of time depends upon the "cooling power" of the air. Each Kata has a "factor" called the Kata Factor marked on the stem. This factor is determined for each instrument by the manufacturers. This factor, divided by the average cooling time gives the rate of cooling in millicalories per sq. centimetre per second. The Kata thermometer was originally devised for measuring the "cooling power" of the air. A dry Kata reading of 6 and above, and a wet Kata reading of 20 and above were regarded as indices of thermal comfort. The Kata thermometer is now largely used as an anemometer for recording low air velocities rather than the cooling power of the air. Kata thermometers are available to cover the following 5 deg.F cooling ranges:
    • The standard Kata-cooling range between 100 ° -95 °F.
    • The High Temperature Kata-cooling range between 130 ° -125 °F. and
    • The Extra High Temperature Kata-cooling range between 150 ° -145 °F.

The three types of Kata are readily distinguished by the colour of the alcohol. The standard Kata is coloured red; the high temperature instrument dark blue; and the extra high instrument magenta. Kata thermometers have silvered bulbs to reduce the errors due to radiation.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg:874

questions.text: Woman gave birth to twins. The father thought the children does not belong to him. DNA fingerprinting was done & it was found that one child belong to him. It is a
questions.solution:
SUPERFECUNDATION: It means the fertilisation of two ova which have been discharged from the ovary at the same period, by two separate acts of coitus committed at short intervals. The incidence of twin pregnancies is about one-and half percent and of these about 70% are binovular twins resulting from separate fertilisation of two ova formed in the same menstrual cycle.

Development of twins in utero is parallel but not equal, depending on the relative blood supplies from the separately formed placentae. Both ova do not always develop to maturity.

One fetus may be aborted early or die and retained until the labour that expels the other. The dead fetus may be flattened by pressure and may not be recognizable and is referred to as fetus compressus or fetus papyraceus. The spermatozoa causing fertilization may be from different men. The rare cases wherein two ova are fertilised by a white and black person or persons with entirely different blood groups are the only certain examples of this condition.

SUPERFOETATION: This means the fertilization of a second ovum in a woman who is already pregnant. Ovulation may occur during first trimester of pregnancy until decidua vera comes into apposition with decidua reflexa and decidual cavity gets obliterated. Fertilization of newly released ovum may occur following coitus.

Later, two fetuses are born either at the same time showing different stages of development or two fully developed fetuses are born at different periods varying from one to three months.

Cases where a second fully developed child was born a considerable time after the first have been explained on the assumption of twin pregnancy, in which the second child did not develop either due to diminished blood supply or some other cause. On the birth of the normally developed child, the second fetus received proper nourishment and is born later as mature child.

SUPPOSITITIOUS CHILDREN: It means fictitious children. A woman may pretend pregnancy and delivery and later produce a living child as her own or she may substitute a male child for female child born of her or for an abortion. This is done for obtaining money or for the purpose of claiming property.

Other legal issues involved are blackmailing a man or bringing a charge of breech of promise of marriage against a man. In such cases, the woman should be examined for signs of pregnancy and delivery. The medical evidence is useful only when the age of the supposititious child does not correspond to the date of the pretended delivery. DNA fingerprinting will be conclusive.

ATAVISM: The child does not resemble its parents but resembles its grandparents. This is due to inheritance of characteristics from remote instead of from immediate ancestors, due to a chance recombination of genes. Any mental or physical characteristic or tendency or disease peculiar to a remote ancestor may be inherited.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 370

questions.text: A child diagnosed as UTI was administered an antibiotic following which he developed tendon rupture. What would be the mechanism of action of that drug?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of action

  • The FQs inhibit the enzyme bacterial DNA gyrase(primarily active in gram negative bacteria)
  • In gram-positive bacteria the major target of FQ action is a similar enzyme topoisomerase IV which nicks and separates daughter DNA strands after DNA replication. Greater affinity of a FQ for topoisomerase IV may confer higher potency against gram-positive bacteria.
  • The bactericidal action probably results from digestion of the DNA by exonucleases whose production is signalled by the damaged DNA.

Side effects of FQs

Gastrointestinal: nausea, vomiting, bad taste, anorexia. Because gut anaerobes are not affected-diarrhoea is infrequent.

  • CNS: dizziness, headache, restlessness, anxiety, insomnia, impairment of concentration and dexterity (caution while driving).
  • Skin/hypersensitivity: rash, pruritus, photosensitivity, urticaria, swelling of lips, etc. Serious cutaneous reactions are rare.
  • Tendonitis and tendon rupture Due to reports of cartilage damage, FQs should be used cautiously in children.

Ciprofloxacin and other FQs are contraindicated during pregnancy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 760

questions.solution:
• Local anesthesia systemic toxicity can be treated with 20% intralipid emulsion along with CPR if the patient becomes unconscious.
  • Cardiotoxicity and CNS toxicity are seen in the toxicity of local anesthetics like bupivacaine and levobupivacaine.
  • Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes of administration and cerebral bupivacaine content by 18% within 15 minutes of administration.

Reference: Miller's anesthesia, 9th edition, pg 885

questions.text: Which of the following is not the complication of massive transfusion?
questions.solution:
Complications of blood transfusion

Complications from blood transfusion can be categorized as those arising from a single transfusion and those related to massive transfusion.

Complications from a single transfusion:

  • Incompatibility haemolytic transfusion reaction;
  • Febrile transfusion reaction;
  • Allergic reaction;
  • Infection;
  • Bacterial infection (usually due to faulty storage);
  • Hepatitis;
  • HIV;
  • Malaria;
  • Air embolism;
  • Thrombophlebitis;
  • Transfusion related acute lung injury (usually from FFP).

Complications from massive transfusion:

  • Coagulopathy;
  • Hypocalcaemia;
  • Hyperkalaemia;
  • Hypokalaemia;
  • Hypothermia;

Reference: Bailey and Love's short practice of surgery, 28th edition, part 1, chapter 2, page no 22.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented with a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
For a pulsatile supraclavicular mass the most appropriate investigation would be doppler USG to determine the nature of lesion as vascular or non vascular.

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology, page no. 353

questions.text: A preeclampsia patient presented with absent bilateral plantar reflex. Lungs clear, RBS-200+, patellar reflex absent. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Symptoms of magnesium sulfate toxicity are seen with the following maternal serum concentrations: loss of deep tendon reflexes (9.6-12 mg/dL) (> 7 mEq/L), respiratory depression (12-18 mg/dL) (> 10 mEq/L), and cardiac arrest (24-30mg/dL) (> 25mEq/L).

Mnemonic

Calcium gluconate:

  • The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate 1 g IV over 3 minutes.
  • Repeat doses may be necessary.
  • Calcium chloride can also be used in lieu of calcium gluconate.
  • The suggested dose for calcium chloride for magnesium toxicity is 500 mg of 10% calcium chloride IV given over 5-10 minutes.

Reference: Dutta's textbook of obstetrics, 9th edition, chapter 17, page no. 219; Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Chapter 41, Clinical management of preeclampsia syndrome, Page no. 1861

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presents with a vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area would mostly be affected?
questions.solution:
At the inferior Frontal Gyrus, there is Broca's Area, which Helps, in the expressive speech With Brodmann Number 44.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, page no. 698

questions.text: Patient with mediastinal mass was diagnosed with red cell aplasia. What is the most probable cause of aplasia?
questions.solution:
Most common primary tumour present in the anterior superior mediastinum is thymoma. Although thymus is a lymphoepithelial organ, the term thymoma is used for the tumour of epithelial origin. Most of the patients are adults. In about half the cases, thymoma remains asymptomatic and is accidentally discovered in X-rays. Other patients have associated conditions like myasthenia gravis or local symptoms such as cough, dyspnoea and chest pain.

MORPHOLOGIC FEATURES

Grossly, the tumour is spherical, measuring 5-10 cm in diameter with an average weight of 150 gm. Sectioned surface is soft, yellowish, lobulated and may be either homogeneous or contain cysts due to the presence of haemorrhage and necrosis.

Microscopically, the tumour has a thick fibrous capsule from which extends collagenous septa into the tumour dividing it into lobules. The histology of lobule shows various patterns. The tumour consists of neoplastic epithelial cells and a variable number of non-neoplastic lymphocytes.

Thymoma may be of following types:

Benign thymoma is more common. It consists of epithelial cells which are similar to the epithelial cells in the medulla of thymus and hence also called medullary thymoma.

Malignant thymoma is less common and is further of 2 types:

Type 1 is cytologically benign looking but aggressive and invades the mediastinal structures locally.

Type 2 is also called thymic carcinoma and has cytologic features of cancer. Further subtypes of epithelial malignancy may be squamous cell type (most common) and lymphoepithelial type. T

Thymomas are known for their association with paraneoplastic syndrome. These include: myasthenia gravis (most common), hypogammaglobulinemia, erythroid hypoplasia (pure red cell aplasia), peripheral T cell leukaemia/lymphoma, multiple myeloma, other autoimmune disease associations and other systemic malignancies.

Reference: Textbook of Pathology, Harsh Mohan, 7th ed, Pg no. 369

questions.text: A female from a tribal area of Jharkhand reports having a fever for the last 3 days. Peripheral blood is collected and stained with Giemsa. A diagnosis of malaria is made. The smear is shown in the figure. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Given case is Malaria. Blood picture shows ring structure. The Rings of P vivax and P falciparum are different. Gametocytes are also different in shapes.

In vivax in RBC one ring is seen and Falciparum multiple rings are seen.

The Vivax, the ring is bigger than the falciparum ring.

Because the gametocyte of P Falciparum is banana shaped Or sausage shaped with pale blue or pink cytoplasm, large nucleus

Macrogamete are - crescentic deep blue cytoplasm, compact nucleus

While p Vivax microgamete are Spherical, compact pale blue cytoplasm diffuse nucleus, the macrogamete large spherical deep blue cytoplasm

Reference: Chatterjee, 12th Edition, Pg: 79

questions.text:
You are a PHC officer now in a earthquake prone zone. What is your job as a MO in disaster management?
1) Giving instructions over phone or radio
2) Simulation of the disaster and assessing response
3) Public health education
4) Preparedness at PHC level by utilising resources
questions.solution:
DISASTER PREPAREDNESS

  • Emergency preparedness is "a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It should bring about an orderly transition from relief through recovery, and back to sustained development".
  • The objective of disaster preparedness is to ensure that appropriate systems, procedures and resources are in place to provide prompt effective assistance to disaster victims thus facilitating relief measures and rehabilitation of services.
  • Disaster preparedness is an on-going multisectoral activity. It forms an integral part of the national system responsible for developing plans and programmes for disaster management, prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation and reconstruction. The system, known by a variety of names depending on the country, depends on the coordination of a variety of sectors to carry out the following tasks:
    1. Evaluate the risk of the country or particular region to disaster;
    2. Adopt standards and regulations;
    3. Organize communication, information and warning systems;
    4. Ensure coordination and response mechanisms;
    5. Adopt measures to ensure that financial and other resources are available for increased readiness and can be mobilized in disaster situation;
    6. Develop public education programmes;
    7. Coordinate information sessions with news media; and
    8. Organize disaster simulation excercises that test response mechanisms.

Giving instructions over phone or radio is not a part of disaster preparedness.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no. 925

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint: Ulnar nerve palsy
Dynamic cock up splint: Radial nerve palsy
Knuckle bender splint: Medial Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly matched statement regarding the splint shown in image
questions.solution:
The image shows a dynamic cock up splint which is used in wrist drop. Wrist drop is caused by Radial nerve injury.

Turn buckle splint: A dynamic splint producing gradual stretching over contracted joints by its turnbuckle mechanism.

Indications:

  1. Stiff elbow
  2. VIC
  • Knuckle bender splint: Based on the principle of 3 point fixation. When all fingers are loaded with flexion, the extended MCP joint tends to achieve a position of flexion.
  • Static cock up splint: Maintain wrist in extension with the help of volar support.
    Indications: Sprain, Arthritis, Tendinitis of wrist.
  • Dynamic cock up splint: Maintains wrist in 45 degrees of extension.
    Indications: Radial nerve palsy

Reference: Upendra Kumar's; Bedside clinics in Orthopaedics, Page no. 220.

questions.text: A female comes with a year old history of contact lens present with eye pain, irritation and foreign body sensation. Spot the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC) is when the inside of your eyelid gets red, swollen and irritated. Without GPC, the inside of your eyelid is very smooth.

People who wear contact lenses (especially soft lenses) have the greatest chance of getting GPC. GPC can happen at any time, even after wearing contacts for many years.

People who do not wear contact lenses can also get GPC. But this is rare, mostly affecting those who have an artificial eye or stitches.

In giant papillary conjunctivitis, large bumps appear on the underside of the eyelid.

GPC Causes

GPC seems to be caused by the following:

  • An allergy, either to contact lenses or the chemicals used to clean them. Contact lens wearers with asthma, hay fever or other allergies are more likely to get GPC.
  • A contact lens, artificial eye or exposed stitches rubbing against the eyelid
  • Deposits of proteins or other substances on the contact lenses
  • Chronic eye allergies

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, chapter 6, pg no. 186, GPC.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 16 kg is scheduled for hernia repair under general anesthesia. Assuming he was NPO for 8 hours, his total fluid deficit will be about _____ (mL):
questions.solution:
Maintenance requirements for pediatric patients can be determined by the "4:2:1 rule":

  • 4 mL/kg/h for the first 10 kg of weight
  • 2 mL/kg/h for the second 10 kg
  • 1 mL/kg/h for each remaining kilogram

Thus, using above formula, total fluid deficit would be 40 + (6 × 2) = 52 mL/h

Accounting for 8 hours of fasting, total fluid deficit will be 52 × 8 = 416 mL

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anesthesiology 6th edition pg. 915.

questions.text: Test for diagnosis of HSV encephalitis?
questions.solution:
• The primary diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis is CSF PCR. It is 96% sensitive and 99% specific. It has got a fairly high negative predictive value, if the pretest probability of HSV is low. It is not affected by antiviral treatment for up to 7 days. Only 20% CSF samples will be positive after 2 weeks of illness.
  • The CSF antibody testing also aids in diagnosis of herpes simplex virus encephalitis. But the detection of antigens and antibodies typically occurs after one week of the infection, which makes acute diagnosis impossible with antibodies. Useful in patients with more than one week of infection, and in whom CSF PCR is negative.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, Page number: 1102-1111.

choices.text: Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR
Use MR and discard Pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: ANM has to conduct vaccination camp in a village and she received 2 open vials of pentavalent vaccine and MR. What should be done next:
questions.solution:
OPEN VIAL POLICY:

  • Implementation of open vial policy allows reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under UIP in subsequent session(both fixed and outreach) upto four weeks(28 days) subject to meeting certain conditions and thus reduce vaccine wastage.
  • Open Vial policy applies for:
    1. DPT,
    2. TT,
    3. Hepatitis B,
    4. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV),
    5. Liquid Pentavalent,
    6. PCV and
    7. injectable IPV.
  • Does not apply to:
    1. Measles/MR, - should be used with 6 hours
    2. BCG,- should be used with 6 hours
    3. Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccines, - should be used within 2 hours
    4. Rota virus - should be used with 6 hours
    5. Covaxin/covishield
  • Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one immunization session upto four weeks provided:
    1. Expiry date has not passed.
    2. Vaccines are stored strictly under appropriate temperature range both during transportation & storage at cold chain point.
    3. Vaccine vial septum has not submerged in water or contaminated in any way. Aseptic technique has been used to withdraw all doses.
    4. Vaccine vial monitor (VVM), has not reached discard point.
  • Open vials should never be submerged in water (e.g. Water accumulated in vaccine carrier) as it increases the risk of contamination of the vial septum.
  • Ensure all open vials have recorded date and time of opening.
  • At the end of the session, all open vials should be returned to Cold Chain Point.
  • At Cold Chain Point, open vials should be segregated into:
    1. Re-usable DPT, TT, Hepatitis B and Pentavalent vaccine vials fulfilling the above mentioned criteria.
    2. Non-reusable open vials of Measles/MR, BCG & JE.
  • All open vials of BCG, Measles and JE should be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier
  • In case of any AEFI reported, all open vials (usable & non-usable) should not be discarded or used. All open vials should be stored under proper cold chain till investigation is complete.
  • All vials (open or unopened) should be transported in a zipper bag in the vaccine carrier and recorded in the stock register.
  • Well-sealed conditioned ice-packs should be used in vaccine carriers and water should not be allowed to accumulate where vaccine vials and diluents are stored.
  • Discard vaccines returned unused for >3 times
  • Here, open vial policy Canberra applied for pentavalent vaccine but not for measles vaccine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no. 121

questions.text: A 30 year old patient came with flaccid bullae which rupture easily on touch. The biopsy from the lesion is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is an autoimmune, intraepithelial, blistering disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes.
  • Mediated by circulating autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3.
  • The principal antigen implicated in PV is desmoglein 3.
  • The binding of antibody to desmoglein damages the adherence and triggers a cellular process that results in acantholysis
  • Patient presents with flaccid bullae and painful erosion along with mucosal involvement - painful oral ulcers.
  • HPE: suprabasal blister, row of tombstones appearance.
  • In PF, acantholysis occurs in the upper epidermis, subcorneal split.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 50, page no. 50.7

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in brain
questions.solution:
Congenital cerebral aneurysms:

  • These occur mostly on the vessels of circulus arteriosus, particularly at or near the junction of two arteries involved in the formation of the circle of Willis.
  • The basic abnormality at these points is the congenital deficiency of tunica media in the arterial wall.
  • The aneurysms are berry shaped (saccular) so known as berry or saccular aneurysm.
  • The Subarachnoid hemorrhage commonly results from rupture of these aneurysms.

Reference: Textbook Neuroanatomy by Vishram Singh, 4th Edition, Page No. 180

questions.solution:
Biomedical waste guides are revised with time to time, the most recent guidelines are as below.

questions.text: A 55-years old man had been working in a Benzene factory for long time. He got retired 5years ago. What could be a possible complication?
questions.solution:
OCCUPATIONAL CANCER

  1. SKIN CANCER
    • It was found that cancer of the scrotum and of the skin in other parts of the body was caused by coal tar, X-rays, certain oils and dyes.
    • Skin cancers are an occupational hazard among gas workers, coke oven workers, tar distillers, oil refiners, dye-stuff makers, road makers and in industries associated with the use of mineral oil, pitch, tar and related compounds.
  2. LUNG CANCER
    • Lung cancer is a hazard in gas industry, asbestos industry, nickel and chromium work, arsenic roasting plants and in the mining of radio-active substances(e.g., uranium). Nickel, chromates, asbestos, coal tar(presumably 3-4 benzpyrene), radio-active substances and cigarette-smoking are proved carcinogens for the lungs.
    • Arsenic, beryllium and isopropyl oil are suspected carcinogens.
  3. CANCER BLADDER
    • Cancer bladder was first noted in man in aniline industry.
    • In more recent years, it was noted in the rubber industry.
    • It is now known that cancer bladder is caused by aromatic amines, which are metabolized in the body and excreted in the urine. The industries associated with cancer bladder are the dye-stuffs and dyeing industry, rubber, gas and the electric cable industries. The following have been mentioned as possible bladder carcinogens. Betanaphthylamines, benzidine, para-amino-diphenyl, auramine and magenta.
  4. Leukemia
    • Exposure to benzene, roentgen rays and radio-active substances give rise to leukemia.
    • Benzene is a dangerous chemical and is used as a solvent in many industries.

The characteristics of occupational cancer are:

  • They appear after prolonged exposure.
  • The period between exposure and development of the disease may be as long as 10 to 25 years
  • The disease may develop even after the cessation of exposure
  • The average age incidence is earlier than that for cancer in general
  • The localization of the tumours is remarkably constant in any one occupation Control of industrial cancer.

The control measures comprise the following:

  • Elimination or control of industrial carcinogens. Technical measures like exclusion of the carcinogen from the industry, well-designed building or machinery, closed system of production, etc.,
  • Medical examinations
  • Inspection of factories
  • Notification
  • Licensing of establishments
  • Personal hygiene measures
  • Education of workers and management and
  • Research

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no. 935

questions.text: A patient with hysteria was hyperventilating. He developed carpopedal spasm. What is the acid base abnormality?
questions.solution:
• In hyperventilation, there will be CO2 wash out and respiratory alkalosis.
  • Chronic respiratory alkalosis is the commonest acid base anomaly in critically ill patients and indicates a poor prognosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, page number: 368

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents with cyclical abdominal pain with a suprapubic bulge. On examination, there is a bluish vaginal bulge present. What is the mostly likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The hymen is formed by invagination of the posterior wall of the urogenital sinus and usually undergoes spontaneous dissolution during the perinatal period.
  • Imperforate hymen commonly occurs as an isolated anatomical defect, although in a minority, additional müllerian anomalies involving higher levels of the outflow tract may coexist.
  • The HPO axis is intact, and the uterine endometrium is responsive to cyclic ovarian hormonal fluctuations with cyclic shedding of the menstrual endometrium.
  • There is a progressive buildup of the menstrual blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and the endometrial cavity (hematometra).
  • Typically, the clinical presentation is that of primary amenorrhea in the setting of normal secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Proximate to the time of anticipated menarche, patients with an imperforate hymen start experiencing worsening cyclic perineal, pelvic, or abdominal pressure or pain that results from the gradual accumulation of obstructed menstrual flow (cryptomenorrhea).
  • Patients may present with acute urinary retention due to compression of the urethra and bladder by a grossly distended lower vagina.
  • Examination of the external genitalia reveals no obvious vaginal orifice and a thin, often bulging, blue perineal membrane at the inferior limit of a palpable, fluctuant mass (hematocolpos). This blue bulging membrane at the introitus becomes prominent during a Valsalva manoeuvre.
  • The treatment of girls with an imperforate hymen centers on providing relief of symptoms related to the accumulated menstrual fluid and debris.
  • Definitive surgery should be accomplished as soon as possible because delay can lead to infertility due to inflammatory changes and to the development of severe endometriosis.
  • Surgical correction of an imperforate hymen is straightforward. The classical procedure is to make a simple cruciate incision in the bulging hymen extending to the base of the hymenal ring and to excise its central portion to allow drainage of the sequestered menstrual fluid and subsequent normal menstrual egress (FENTON'S OPERATION).

Reference: Speroff's Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology & Infertility, Chapter 10, Amenorrhea, Page no. 856-857

questions.text: A smoker was on nicotine therapy for smoking dependence and was on clonidine for hypertension. He stopped clonidine but continued nicotine and eventually developed a headache. Which of the following is the most accurate mechanism for the development of headache in this patient?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Clonidine

  • Sedation, mental depression, disturbed sleep; dryness of mouth, nose and eyes (secretion is decreased by central action), constipation (antisecretory effect on the intestines).
  • Impotence, salt and water retention, bradycardia.
  • Postural hypotension occurs, but is mostly asymptomatic.
  • Alarming rise in BP, in excess of pretreatment level, with tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, sweating, headache, nausea and vomiting occur in some patients when doses of clonidine are missed for 1-2 days. The syndrome is very similar to that seen in pheochromocytoma: plasma catecholamine (CA) concentration is increased.

This is due to:

(a) Sudden removal of central sympathetic inhibition resulting in release of large quantities of stored CAs.

(b) Supersensitivity of peripheral adrenergic structures to CAs that develops due to chronic reduction of sympathetic tone during clonidine therapy.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 611

questions.text: A 4 year old baby had developed a cherry red spot on the macula. The child suffered from mental retardation, skeletal muscle weakness. Hepatosplenomegaly was not present. Following was the result of the fundoscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Causes of cherry red spot

  • GM2 gangliosidoses(Tay sachs & sandhoff)
  • Hurler's syndrome
  • GM1 gangliosidosis
  • Cryoglobulinemia
  • Niemann - Pick's disease
  • Laber's congenital amaurosis
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Sialidosis(galactosialidosis)
  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy
  • Mucopolysacharidosis VII
  • Central retinal artery occlusion(CRAO)
  • Multiple sulfatase deficiency
  • Trauma(Berlin's edema/commotio retinae)
  • Poisoning: Carbon mono-oxide, methanol
  • Quinine and Dapsone
  • Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome
  • Farber's disease
  • Hallervorden Spatz disease
  • Goldberg's disease
  • Rarely in krabbe's disease

Both Tay sachs disease and Niemann pick causes Cherry red spot, however only Tay sachs causes mental retardation.

Hence, the patient described in this condition is of Tay sachs disease.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye 22nd edition, section IV page no, 339-340

questions.text: A young female presents with a left sided throbbing headache. She also has nausea, vomiting, aura and phonophobia. What is the best treatment for immediate relief ?
questions.solution:
The question deals with treatment of an acute attack of migraine. Among the given options, only Sumatriptan is used for aborting an acute episode. The others are used for prophylaxis of migraine.

The drugs used in acute migraine

  1. Acetaminophen
  2. NSAIDS
  3. HTIB/ID receptor agonists - Triptans-Oral/Nasal/Parenteral
  4. CGRP receptor agonists-Oral-Rimegepant, Ubrogepant
  5. 5HT1F receptor agonists-Ditans-Oral-Lasmiditan No action in vasculature, Safe in cardiovascular diseases
  6. Dopamine receptor agonists-Metoclopramide & domperidone Chlorpromazine, Prochlorperazine.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, Page number: 3362-64.

questions.text: 10/ M child with generalised edema. Cholesterol 238 mg/dl. Urine protein 3+, Stool microscopy was done which shows fat in stools. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Nephrotic syndrome is a constellation of features in different diseases having varying pathogenesis; it is characterised by findings of massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidaemia, lipiduria, and hypercoagulability.

  1. Heavy proteinuria (protein loss of more than 3 gm per 24 hrs) is the chief characteristic of nephrotic syndrome (nephrotic range proteinuria). In children, protein loss is correspondingly less. A small amount of protein (20 to 150 mg/day) normally passes through the glomerular filtration barrier and is reabsorbed by the tubules. But in case of increased glomerular permeability to plasma proteins, excess of protein is filtered out exceeding the capacity of tubules for reabsorption and, therefore, appears in the urine. Another feature of protein loss is its 'selectivity'. A highly-selective proteinuria consists mostly of loss of low molecular weight proteins, while a poorly selective proteinuria is loss of high molecular weight proteins in the urine. In nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria mostly consists of loss of albumin (molecular weight 66,000) in the urine.
  2. Hypoalbuminaemia is produced primarily consequent to urinary loss of albumin, and partly due to increased renal catabolism and inadequate hepatic synthesis of albumin. Often, the plasma albumin level is 1 to 3 gm/dl (normal 3.5 to 5.5 gm/dl) and there is a reversed albumin-globulin ratio. The concentration of other proteins in the plasma such as immunoglobulins, clotting factors and antithrombin may fall rendering these patients more vulnerable to infections and thrombotic and thromboembolic complications.
  3. Oedema in nephrotic syndrome appears due to fall in colloid osmotic pressure consequent upon hypoalbuminemia. Sodium and water retention further contribute to oedema. Nephrotic oedema is usually peripheral but in children facial oedema may be more prominent.
  4. Hyperlipidaemia is a frequent accompaniment of nephrotic syndrome. The exact mechanism of its genesis is not clear. It is hypothesised that the liver, faced with the stress of massive protein synthesis in response to heavy urinary protein loss, also causes increased synthesis of lipoproteins. There are increased blood levels of total lipids, cholesterol, triglycerides, VLDL and LDL but decrease in HDL. Low blood level of HDL is partly due to its loss in the urine
  5. Lipiduria occurs following hyperlipidaemia due to excessive leakiness of the glomerular filtration barrier.
  6. Hypercoagulability Patients with nephrotic syndrome may develop spontaneous arterial or venous thrombosis, renal vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to various factors. These include: increased urinary loss of antithrombin III, hyperfibrinogenemia from increased synthesis in the liver, decreased fibrinolysis, increased platelet aggregation and altered levels of protein C and S.

Reference: Textbook of Pathology, Harsh Mohan, 7th ed, Pg- 648

choices.text: Only A and B are true

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about alpha 1 antitrypsin?
A. Inhibits elastase
B. Deficiency is associated with pan acinar emphysema
C. Inhibits trypsin activating protease
D. Coded by PiMM gene
questions.solution:
α1-Anti-trypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder marked by very low levels of circulating α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) that is caused by mutations that lead to misfolding of α1AT. The major function of α1AT is to inhibit proteases, particularly neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, and proteinase 3, which are released from neutrophils at sites of inflammation. α1AT deficiency leads to the development of pulmonary emphysema because the activity of destructive proteases is not inhibited. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of hepatocellular accumulation of the misfolded α1AT protein. α1AT is a small 394amino acid plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. The gene, located on chromosome 14, is very polymorphic. At least 75 α1AT variants have been identified, denoted alphabetically by their relative migration on an isoelectric gel. The general notation is "Pi" for "protease inhibitor" and an alphabetic letter for the position on the gel; two letters denote the genotype of the two alleles. The most common genotype is PiMM, occurring in 90% of individuals (the "wild-type").

Reference: Robbins, 10th ed, Pg- 658

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant in inheritance?
questions.solution:
Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is characterised by one faulty copy of gene (i.e. mutant allele) in any autosome and one copy of normal allele; disease phenotype is seen in all such individuals. Patients having autosomal dominant inheritance disease have a 50% chance of passing on the disease to the next generation.

Reference: Textbook of Pathology, Harsh Mohan, 7th ed, Pg- 255

questions.text: MDR TB is resistance to
questions.solution:
CLASSIFICATION BASED ON DRUG RESISTANCE

  1. Mono-resistance: Resistance to one first-line anti-TB drug only.
  2. Poly drug resistance: Resistance to more than one first line anti-TB drug (other than both isoniazid and rifampicin).
  3. Multidrug resistance: Resistance to at least both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  4. Extensive drug resistance: Resistance to any fluoroquinolone and Resistance to atleast one additional group A drug- i.e either Bedaquiline or Linezolid or both.
  5. Rifampicin resistance: Resistance to rifampicin detected using phenotypic or genotypic methods, with or without resistance to other anti-TB drugs. It includes any resistance to rifampicin, whether mono-resistance, multidrug resistance, poly drug resistance or extensive drug resistance.
  6. Pre XDR TB: MDR/RR TB + any one fluoroquinolone resistance. Prevention of Drug Resistance : Since incomplete, inadequate and irregular treatment is the main cause of drug resistance, this can be prevented by
    1. Treatment with two or more drugs in combination
    2. Using drugs to which the bacteria are sensitive, and
    3. Ensuring that the treatment is complete, adequate and regular.

MANAGEMENT OF DRUG RESISTANT TUBERCULOSIS

  1. H Mono/ Poly Drug Resistant Tuberculosis
    • Bacilli is Rifampicin sensitive and isoniazid resistant.
    • Levofloxacin replaces INH.
    • Lfx ZRE for 6 months.
    • No Intensive or continuous phase.
    • Extended into 9 months in case of :
      1. In patients with extensive disease.
      2. Uncontrolled co-morbidities.
      3. Extra-pulmonary TB.
      4. Smear positive at the end of 3rd month.
    • In case of skeletal, CNS and miliary TB: Extended for 1 year.
    • If Smear positive at the end of 5th month- considered as treatment failure.
  2. MDR/XDR Tuberculosis

A. SHORTER ORAL BEDAQUILINE CONTAINING MDR/XDR TB REGIMEN

  • A shorter oral Bedaquiline-containing MDR/RR-TB regimen of 9-11 months duration is recommended in eligible patients with confirmed MDR/RR-TB who have not been exposed to treatment with second-line TB medicines used in this regimen for more than 1 month, and in whom resistance to fluoroquinolones has been excluded.
  • Given for 9-11 months.
  • Intensive phase: 4-6 months.
  • Continuous phase: 5 months.
  • Bedaquiline for 6 months.

B. LONGER ORAL MDR/XDR TB REGIMEN

  • Include:
    1. Bedaquiline for 6 months and
    2. 18-20 months of following drugs:
      1. Levofloxacin
      2. Linezolid
      3. Clofazimine
      4. Cycloserine
    3. No Intensive and Continuous phase
  • The duration of Bedaquiline is limited to 6 months. Extension beyond 6 months is to be considered in patients in whom an effective regimen cannot otherwise be designed if only 2 of 5 drugs are available from Groups A & B and adequate number of Group C drugs are not available due to high background resistance, non-availability or unreliability of DST.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no 222

questions.text: Patient with h/o opioid overdose presented with severe respiratory depression. DOC for reversal of respiratory depression
questions.solution:
In cases of opioid overdose, the most critical and life-threatening complication is respiratory depression. Opioids act on the central nervous system, including the brainstem, where they suppress the respiratory drive. This can lead to severely decreased or even stopped breathing, which is a medical emergency.

The drug of choice for reversing opioid-induced respiratory depression is naloxone, an opioid antagonist. Naloxone competitively binds to opioid receptors, displacing the opioids and rapidly reverses the effects of the opioids. It restores normal respiration and can save a person's life during an opioid overdose.

Other options:

A. Oral Naltrexone: Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist similar to naloxone, but it is not the best choice in an acute opioid overdose situation. Oral naltrexone takes longer to be absorbed and act, making it less suitable for emergencies like severe respiratory depression in an opioid overdose.

C. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist and antagonist used for opioid replacement therapy and managing opioid use disorder. While it can help with opioid withdrawal and cravings in a controlled setting, it is not the first-line choice for emergency reversal of opioid overdose and respiratory depression.

D. Flumazenil: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose. It is not effective for opioid overdose or respiratory depression caused by opioids.

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, Seventh Edition, by Niraj Ahuja, Page no. 45

questions.text: Poor prognostic marker for multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Serum β2 microglobulin:

  • Estimation of serum β2 microglobulin, either alone or in combination with other parameters, is useful for predicting duration of survival and prognosis in MM.
  • In southwest Oncology Group study, median survival was found to be 3 years with pretreatment serum β2 microglobulin level ≤6 µg/ml, while median survival was less than 2 years for those with values >6 µg/ml.
  • If combined with serum albumin or age, then patients could be stratified into three distinct groups-low-risk, intermediate risk, and high-risk with increasingly shorter median survival.

Reference: Essentials of haematology, 2nd ed, Pg- 326

questions.text: A study had a normal distribution with the median value as 200 and standard deviation 20, then 68% population will fall between:
questions.solution:
NORMAL DISTRIBUTION

  • The normal distribution or 'normal curve' is an important concept in statistical theory. Let us suppose, we collect the haemoglobin values of a very large number of people and make a frequency distribution with narrow class intervals, we are likely to get a smooth, symmetrical curve. Such a curve is called a normal distribution or normal curve.
  • It is useful to note that in a normal curve:
    1. The area between one standard deviation on either side of the mean ( x ± 1 σ) will include approximately 68% of the values in the distribution,
    2. The area between two standard deviations on either side of the mean (x ± 2σ) will cover most of the values, i.e., approximately 95% of the values and
    3. The area between (x ± 3σ ) will include 99. 7% of the values.
  • These limits on either side of the mean are called "confidence limits"
  • Supposing we are considering the 95% confidence limits (x ± 2σ). When we say this, we mean that 95% of the area of the normal curve, and hence 95% of the values in the distribution will be included between the limits x ± 2σ . Therefore, the probability of a reading falling outside the 95% confidence limits is 1 in 20 (P = 0.05).

Standard normal curve

  • The standard normal curve is a smooth, bell-shaped, perfectly symmetrical curve, based on an infinitely large number of observations.
  • The total area of the curve is 1; its mean is zero; and its standard deviation is 1. The mean, median and mode all coincide.
  • The distance of a value(x) from the mean(x) of the curve in units of standard deviation is called "relative deviate or standard normal variate" and is usually denoted by Z.
  • The standard normal deviate or Z is given by the formula: Z= x - x / σ
  • A random variable (x) is said to have been standardized when it has been adjusted so that its mean is zero and its standard deviation is 1.
  • Standardization can be effected by subtracting the mean of x, from x and dividing the resulting difference by σ, the standard deviation of x. Thus x - x / σ is a standardized variable.
  • An important concept of σ mathematical statistics is that the new variate "Z" like the variate "x" also follows a normal distribution. The mean of the transformed distribution is zero (0) and the standard deviation (σ) is 1. Areas under the standard normal curve are frequently needed. They have been computed for values of different relative deviate x - x/ σ.

SUMMARY

  • Is also known as 'Gaussian distribution' or 'Standard distribution'
  • Bilaterally symmetrical, bell-shaped
  • Based on mean (x) and standard deviation (σ)
  • Mean, Median and Mode coincide (Mean = Median = Mode)
  • Has Mean (x) = 0 and SD (σ) = 1
  • Normal distribution, SD (σ) = 1, thus Variance = 1
  • Mean ± 1 SD (x±1σ) covers 68% values
  • Mean ± 2 SD (x±2σ) covers 95% values
  • Mean ± 3 SD (x±3σ) covers 99% values
  • Actual parameters in a Normal(Gaussian) distribution:
    1. Mean ± 1SD (x ± 1σ) limits include 68.27% values
    2. Mean ± 2SD (x ± 2σ) limits include 95.45% values
    3. Mean ± 1.96SD (x ± 1.96σ) limits include 95% values
    4. Mean ± 3SD (x ± 3σ) limits include 99.73% values
    5. Mean ± 2.58SD (x ± 2.58σ) limits include 99% values

APPROACH

Mean ± 1 SD should lie between 68% population.

Here median= 200. In Normal distribution curve, mean= median= Mode

Hence, mean= 200

Answer: (200-20) to (200+ 20) = 180-220

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no 977

questions.text: A child was fatigued after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Glycogen storage disease is a generic term to describe a group of inherited disorders characterized by deposition of an abnormal type or quantity of glycogen in tissues or failure to mobilize glycogen.

Option A: Myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle syndrome) leads to poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high (2.5 -- 4%); blood lactate very low after exercise.

Option B: Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency can lead to Von Gierke disease, which is characterized by glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells; hypoglycemia; lactic acidemia; ketosis; hyperlipidemia.

Option C: Tarui disease occurs due to deficiency of muscle and erythrocyte phosphofructokinase 1. It is characterized by poor exercise tolerance; muscle glycogen abnormally high (2.5 -- 4%); blood lactate very low after exercise; also, hemolytic anemia.

Option D: Andersen disease (Amylopectinosis) occurs due to defects in branching enzymes. It is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly; accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points; death from heart or liver failure before age 5.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, CH 18, Pg 167

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient presented to emergency with acute abdominal pain and distention. A fluid filled lesion is present in the epigastric region. Which of the following parameters will be raised?
questions.solution:
• A 40 years old male patient presented to emergency with acute abdominal pain and distention and A fluid filled lesion is present in the epigastric region suggesting acute pancreatitis. And serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase in pancreatitis.
  • Estimation of pancreatic enzymes in body fluids
    • When the pancreas is damaged, enzymes such as amylase, lipase, trypsin, elastase and chymotrypsin are released into the serum.
    • Measurement of serum amylase is the most widely used test of pancreatic damage (serum lipase is more sensitive and specific but is not widely available).
    • The serum amylase rises within a few hours of pancreatic damage and declines over the next 4-8 days.
    • A markedly elevated serum level is highly suspicious but not diagnostic of acute pancreatitis.
    • Urinary amylase and amylase-creatinine clearance ratios add little to diagnostic accuracy.
    • If confirmation of the diagnosis is required, computed tomography (CT) of the pancreas is of greater value.

Reference: Bailey and Love's short practice of surgery 28th edition, part 11, chapter 72, page no 1262.

The test is considered positive if the hair has deep, narrow wedge shaped perforation in it.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that is done to limit the spread of infection in HIV patients?
questions.solution:
Evisceration Methods (Techniques of autopsy) :

  1. Letulle's technique:
    • Described by Letulle.
    • Also known as, 'En masse' or 'En bloc' dissection
    • En masse = In a group; altogether
    • En bloc = All together or all at the same time
    • In this technique, oral, cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one large organ block.
    • Leaves all attachments intact.
    • Commonly done in medical colleges to teach students
  2. Virchow's Method:
    • Organ by organ removal
    • Individual organ removal one by one.
    • Subsequent dissection of isolated organs.
    • Useful for assessing individual organ pathology.
    • Quick and effective for single organ focus.
    • Most common method in India
  3. Gohn's technique:
    • Developed by Ghon.
    • Also known as, 'Block by block' dissection
    • Cervical & thoracic organs, abdominal organs and the urogenital system are removed as separate organ blocks.
  4. In Situ Dissection:
    • Developed by Rokitansky.
    • Also known as In-situ dissection
    • Organs dissected in situ with minimal evisceration.
    • Rarely performed.
    • Done in infected & suspected infection cases.

Reference: Knight's Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Page N0. 22; The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 80

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a history of 2 weeks amenorrhea came to the emergency department with c/o scanty vaginal bleeding. on examination no adnexal mass noted. In lab investigation HCG was 1400mlU/ml, on USG, the uterus was bulky, trilaminar endometrium was seen. Patient vitals stable, what is the next step to do?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy of Unknown Location

  • If a yolk sac, embryo, or fetus is found within the uterus or within the adnexa, a diagnosis is made. However, if no evidence of an IUP is seen with TVS, the diagnosis is a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL).
  • Most PULs reflect: (1) a failing IUP, (2) recent completed abortion, (3) early IUP, or (4) ectopic pregnancy.
  • Without clear evidence for ectopic pregnancy, serial β-hCG level assessment is reasonable, and a second level is obtained 48 hours after the first.
  • This practice averts unnecessary methotrexate therapy and avoids harming an early, normal IUP.

Reference: Dutta's textbook of obstetrics 9th edition, chapter 7, page no. 64

Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Chapter 12, Ectopic Pregnancy, Page no. 580

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method used to know depth of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:

  • Awareness during anesthesia is a very serious complication with potential long-term psychological sequelae such as anxiety and post-traumatic disorder.
  • When the bispectral index(BIS) value is maintained below 60, it decreases the incidence of anesthesia awareness.
  • Several neuro monitors based on the processed electroencephalogram or evoked potentials have been developed to evaluate the anesthetic depth. The BIS monitor is the first method that is FDA approved to assess the hypnotic effects of drugs.
