questions.text: A 25 years old male patient with an alleged history of road traffic accident sustained injury over chest and abdomen. At the time of presentation, systolic BP was 70 mm Hg and pulse rate was 110/minute. Which of the following is the next step?
questions.solution:
• Focused abdominal sonography for trauma and extended FAST (FAST and eFAST)
  • Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) is a technique whereby ultrasound (sonography) imaging is used to assess the torso for the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity, and is extended into the thoracic cavities and pericardium (eFAST).
  • There should be no attempt to determine the nature or extent of the specific injury.
  • eFAST is usually a rapid, reproducible, portable and non-invasive bedside test and can be performed at the same time as resuscitation. eFAST is accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood; however, it is very operator dependent and, especially if the patient is very obese or the bowel is full of gas, it may be unreliable.
  • Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose, even in experienced hands, as small amounts of gas or fluid are difficult to assess and eFAST has a low sensitivity (29-35%) for organ injury without hemoperitoneum.
  • eFAST is also unreliable for excluding injury in penetrating trauma. If there is doubt, the eFAST examination can be repeated.

Reference: Bailey and Love's short practice of surgery 28th edition, part 4, chapter 29, page no 378

questions.text: Super antigen is produced by which of the following
questions.solution:
Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome is caused by one of the super antigen produced by Streptococcus pyogenes.

Superantigen is a family of highly potent mitogens that share the ability to trigger excessive stimulation of human and other mammalian T lymphocytes.This leads to a massive release of T cell mediators and proinflammatory cytokines contributing to diseases such as Toxic Shock Syndrome.

It also produces necrotizing fasciitis, Kawasaki disease, psoriasis and acute rheumatic fever.

questions.text: Which among these is included in the MELD score?

  • MELD score ranges between 6 and 40.
  • Prioritization of liver transplantation is based on MELD score, since MELD determines the post transplantation mortality and waiting list mortality.
  • Score <15 is associated with a high post-transplant mortality

questions.text: A male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease was prescribed theophylline. He noticed that his urine output had increased the following day. This action of the drug is mediated through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of action

Three distinct cellular actions of methylxanthines have been defined-

(a) Release of Ca2+ from sarcoplasmic reticulum, especially in skeletal and cardiac muscle.

(b) Inhibition of phosphodiesterase (PDE) which degrades cyclic nucleotides intracellularly. Bronchodilation, cardiac stimulation and vasodilation occur, and mediator release is inhibited when cAMP level rises in the bronchial/cardiac/vascular smooth muscle and in inflammatory cells, respectively.

(c) Blockade of adenosine receptors: adenosine acts as a local mediator in CNS, CVS and other organs. Adenosine contracts smooth muscles, especially bronchial; dilates cerebral blood vessels, depresses cardiac pacemaker and inhibits gastric secretion. Methylxanthines produce opposite effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 246

questions.text: Identify the arrow marked structure in the microscopic picture
questions.solution:
• The kidney is covered by a capsule.
  • Deep to the capsule there is the cortex.
  • Deep to the cortex there is the medulla of the kidney.
  • In the cortex we see circular structures called renal corpuscles surrounding tubules cut in various shapes.
  • The dark pink stained tubules are parts of the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT): their lumen is small and indistinct. It is lined by cuboidal epithelium with a brush
  • Lighter staining tubules, each with a distinct lumen, are the distal convoluted tubules (DCT). They are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium.
  • PCTs are more in number than DCT.
  • In the medulla we see very light staining, elongated, parallel running tubules. These are collecting ducts and loops of Henle. Some of them extend into the cortex forming a medullary ray.
  • The collecting ducts are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium and the loop of Henle (thin segments) are lined by simple squamous epithelium.
  • Cut sections of blood vessels are seen both in the cortex and medulla.

Reference: I. B. Singh's textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page No - 209 to 212

questions.text: Q-SOFA components?
questions.solution:
• SOFA score aids physicians in identifying sepsis/septic shock at the bedside by the SEPSIS 3 clinical criteria.
  • SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment score) is a 24 point measurement of major organ dysfunction (Renal, cardiac, pulmonary, neurological, hematological and hepatic), where 0-4 points are assigned for each organ system.
  • The SEPSIS 3 clinical criteria include:
    1. A suspected or documented
    2. Acute increase in≥ 2 Sepsis related organ failure assessment (SOFA)

  • The qSOFA(Quick SOFA) is a simplified and validated criteria introduced by the SEPSIS 3 which predicts poor outcome for hospitalized patients with sepsis.
  • It includes only three parameters and each if present will be given a score of 1.
    1. GCS<15
    2. RR>20
    3. SBP<100

questions.text: A child is presented with loose stools multiple times. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glucose and galactose are absorbed by a sodium-dependent process. They are carried by the same transport protein (SGLT 1) and compete with each other for intestinal absorption.

SGLT 1 is present in small intestine and kidney.

Option B: SGLT 2 is responsible for reabsorption of glucose filtered by the kidney.

Option C: GLUT 4 present in heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue. Mediate Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake.

Option D: GLUT 2 present in liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, kidney. Mediate rapid uptake or release of glucose.

questions.text: An anesthetist injected bupivacaine in a patient for axillary nerve block. Later, the patient developed restlessness, agitation and cardiovascular collapse. Next best step in the management would be?
questions.solution:
Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anaesthetic

  • At toxic doses, local anaesthetics can result in CNS (convulsions) or CVS (hypotension, bradycardia, arrhythmias) symptoms.
  • Diazepam is used to treat convulsions. If not responding, thiopentone may be used.
  • Arrhythmias should be promptly treated using bretylium, amiodarone, disopyramide, magnesium sulphate, esmolol or sotalol.
  • Lignocaine should be avoided as antiarrhythmic because it can exacerbate the CNS toxicity.
  • In refractory arrhythmias, intravenous lipid emulsion (like intralipid) has been found to be extremely useful.
  • Bupivacaine induced cardiotoxicity is enhanced by acidosis, hypercarbia and hypoxemia.

Reference: Ajay Yadav 2nd edition, page110

questions.text: True statement about intermittent claudication:
questions.solution:
• Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the muscles that is:
    • Brought on by walking;
    • Not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis);
    • Relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes).
  • The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day. It is decreased, first, by increasing the work demands and hence oxygen requirements of the muscles affected, e.g. walking up hill, increasing the speed of walking and/or carrying heavy weights, and, second, by general health conditions that reduce the oxygen delivery capacity of the arterial system, e.g. anemia or cardiorespiratory disease.
  • The muscle group affected by claudication is classically one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease and is usually felt in the posterior calf as the superficial femoral artery is the most commonly affected artery (70% of cases).
  • Aortoiliac disease (30% of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication; Leriche' syndrome is buttock claudication combined with sexual impotence, which is secondary to arterial insufficiency

Reference: Bailey and Love's short practice of surgery 28th edition, part 10, chapter 61, page no 998.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of foods which is followed by recurrent vomiting. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The described symptoms of intense cravings for food followed by recurrent vomiting are characteristic of bulimia nervosa. Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder that primarily affects young females and is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating. During these episodes, individuals consume large amounts of food in a short period, often feeling a loss of control during the process. To compensate for the excessive food intake and prevent weight gain, individuals with bulimia nervosa engage in behaviors like self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives or diuretics, fasting or excessive exercise.

Other options:

A. Anorexia nervosa: Anorexia nervosa is another eating disorder, but it involves a different pattern of behavior. Individuals with anorexia nervosa have a fear of gaining weight and they restrict their food intake significantly, leading to severe weight loss and potentially dangerously low body weight.

C. Atypical depression: Atypical depression is a subtype of major depressive disorder(MDD), characterized by mood reactivity(ability to experience improved mood in response to positive events), increased appetite or weight gain, excessive sleep and feeling of heaviness in the limbs. While appetite changes are present, the described pattern of intense cravings followed by recurrent vomiting is not typical for atypical depression.

D. Binge eating disorder: While the term "binge eating" is present in this option, it is important to distinguish binge eating disorder from bulimia nervosa. In binge eating disorder, individuals have recurrent episodes of binge eating similar to bulimia nervosa, but without compensatory behaviors such as vomiting. The absence of compensatory behaviors is a key distinction between the two disorders.

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, Seventh Edition, by Niraj Ahuja, Page: 144

questions.text: A patient on anti-depression medication presents with elevated body temperature, dilated pupils, palpitations and low bp. ECG shows broad QRS complex tachycardia and right axis deviation. Which of the following interventions must be done immediately?
questions.solution:
• IV sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate may be used in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose to counteract the cardiac toxicity by sodium channel blockade. However, its use should be considered cautiously and is typically reserved for severe cases. In this scenario, while the patient is experiencing broad complex tachycardia, sodium bicarbonate may not be the initial treatment of choice.
  • Esmolol: Esmolol is a beta-blocker that can rapidly control heart rate and blood pressure. However, in this case, where there is a broad complex tachycardia with right axis deviation, indicating a potential ventricular tachycardia, the use of a beta-blocker may exacerbate the condition and is not recommended as the initial treatment.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs: Anti-arrhythmic drugs may be used to manage certain types of tachyarrhythmias. However, the specific choice of anti-arrhythmic depends on the underlying rhythm and the patient's hemodynamic stability. Given the presentation of broad complex tachycardia with right axis deviation, immediate administration of anti-arrhythmic drugs may not be appropriate without further evaluation and confirmation of the rhythm.
  • Wait and watch: Waiting and watching without intervention is not advisable in this scenario. The patient is experiencing significant symptoms and findings on ECG that require prompt medical attention and intervention.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, Page number: 2912-2914

questions.text: Increased pulmonary blood flow is seen in which of the following congenital heart disease?

questions.text: A 36 week pregnant lady with Mitral Valve Replacement was on warfarin. Her INR value is 3'. Next step in the management is?
questions.solution:
• Heart valve replacement with a mechanical valve requires lifelong anticoagulation. Guidelines currently recommend using a vitamin K antagonist (VKA) such as warfarin.
  • Given the teratogenic effects of VKAs, it is often favorable to switch to heparin-derived therapies in pregnant patients since they do not cross the placenta.
  • However, these therapies are known to be less effective anticoagulants subjecting the pregnant patient to a higher chance of a thrombotic event.
  • Planned delivery is recommended in all patients unless obstetric indications call for caesarean section.
  • It is recommended that all women on VKA switch to LMWH or UFH at week 34-36 with induction or caesarean at around 38 weeks.

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Chapter 11 Venous Thromboembolism in pregnancy, Page no. 166

questions.text: When there is low insulin: glucagon ratio. Which of the following enzymes is stimulated?
questions.solution:
Option A: A low insulin: glucagon ratio, will inhibit activity of lipoprotein lipase enzyme, as insulin enhances lipoprotein lipase activity.

Lipoprotein lipase

  • Enzyme leads to hydrolysis of triacylglycerol; Triacylglycerol is hydrolyzed progressively through a diacylglycerol to a monoacylglycerol and finally to FFA plus glycerol. Hydrolysis takes place while the lipoproteins are attached to the enzyme on the endothelium. Catalyzes lipoprotein triacylglycerol hydrolysis before its uptake into extrahepatic tissues.
  • An enzyme located on the walls of blood capillaries, anchored to the endothelium by chains of heparan sulfate (A negatively charged proteoglycan)
  • Found in heart, adipose tissue, spleen, lung, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm and lactating mammary gland, although it is not active in adult liver.
  • Normally not found in blood; however, following injection of heparin, lipoprotein lipase is released from its heparan sulfate-binding sites into the circulation.
  • Both phospholipids and apo C-II are required as cofactors for lipoprotein lipase activity, while apo A-II and apo C-III act as inhibitors.
  • In adipose tissue, insulin enhances lipoprotein lipase synthesis in adipocytes and its translocation to the luminal surface of the capillary endothelium.

Option B: The principal action of insulin in adipose tissue is to inhibit the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, so low insulin: glucagon ratio stimulates enzyme.

Hormone sensitive lipase

  • Triacylglycerol undergoes hydrolysis by a hormone sensitive lipase to form FFA and glycerol. Since the glycerol cannot be utilized, it enters the blood and is taken up and transported to tissues such as the liver and kidney, which possess an active glycerol kinase.
  • The FFA formed by lipolysis can be reconverted in adipose tissue to acyl-CoA by acyl-CoA synthetase and re esterified with glycerol-3-phosphate to form triacylglycerol. Thus, there is a continuous cycle of lipolysis and reesterification within the tissue.
  • However, when the rate of reesterification is not sufficient to match the rate of lipolysis, FFAs accumulate and diffuse into the plasma, where they bind to albumin and raise the concentration of plasma-free fatty acids.
  • The principal action of insulin in adipose tissue is to inhibit the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, reducing the release not only of FFA but also of glycerol. Adipose tissue is much more sensitive to insulin than many other tissues and is thus a major site of insulin action in vivo.

Option C: Phosphofructokinase-1 occupies a key position in regulating glycolysis and is also subject to feedback control. It is inhibited by citrate and by normal intracellular concentrations of ATP and is activated by 5' AMP. At the normal intracellular [ATP] the enzyme is about 90% inhibited; this inhibition is reversed by 5' AMP. A low insulin: glucagon ratio inhibits PFK 1.


Option D: Glycogen synthase is involved in glycogenesis, which is stimulated by high insulin: glucagon ratio. A low ratio inhibits this enzyme.


Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, CH 25, Pg 245

questions.text:
A child is diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following can be seen in this child?

A. Bilious vomiting
B. Visible peristalsis from left to right/ Palpable mass
C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia
D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.solution:
• Nonbilious vomiting is the initial symptom of pyloric stenosis. The vomiting may or may not be projectile initially but is usually progressive, occurring immediately after a feeding. Emesis might follow each feeding, or it may be intermittent. The vomiting usually starts after 3 weeks of age, but symptoms can develop as early as the 1st wk of life and as late as the 5th mo. After vomiting, the infant is hungry and wants to feed again.
  • As vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ion, and chloride leads to hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Greater awareness of pyloric stenosis has led to earlier identification of patients with fewer instances of chronic malnutrition and severe dehydration and at times a subclinical self-resolving hypertrophy.
  • The diagnosis has traditionally been established by palpating the pyloric mass. The mass is firm, movable, approximately 2 cm in length, olive shaped, hard, best palpated from the left side, and located above and to the right of the umbilicus in the mid-epigastrium beneath the liver's edge. The olive is easiest palpated after an episode of vomiting. After feeding, there may be a visible gastric peristaltic wave that progresses across the abdomen.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1496

questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Metoclopramide

  • Sedation, dizziness, loose stools, muscle dystonia (especially in children) are the main side effects.
  • Long-term use can cause parkinsonism, galactorrhoea and gynaecomastia, but it should not be used to augment lactation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is brought with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain, feeling she might have a heart attack/feeling of impending doom. Patient had 5-6 episodes in a month, 30 minutes each, for 6 months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms, including anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain and the feeling of impending doom, along with recurrent episodes lasting for a short duration, are characteristic of panic attacks. Panic disorder is a type of anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks. These attacks are intense and are often associated with a sense of impending doom or fear of losing control.
  • Other options:
    • Depression: While anxiety and depression can coexist, the primary symptoms described in the scenario are consistent with panic attacks rather than depression.
    • C. GAD(Generalized Anxiety Disorder): Generalized Anxiety Disorder involves excessive and uncontrollable worry about various aspects of life, rather than acute episodes of panic as seen in panic disorder.
    • D. Agoraphobia: Agoraphobia involves anxiety about being in situations from which escape might be difficult or embarrassing. While agoraphobia can be associated with panic disorder, the primary diagnosis in this case is panic disorder itself due to the recurrent and intense panic attacks.

Reference: Review of Psychiatry, Based on Kaplan's and Sadock's Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 9th edition and Short Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 6th edition, by Praveen Tripathi, Page no. 43

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and severe calf pain. On examination conjunctival effusion is seen with petechial eruption and thrombocytopenia. The abdomen shows tender hepatomegaly and icterus. KFT is normal and urine microscopic examination shows haematuria. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most patients are asymptomatic or only mildly ill and do not seek medical attention.
  • Serologic evidence of past inapparent infection is frequently found in persons who have been exposed but have not become ill.
  • Mild symptomatic leptospirosis usually presents as a flulike illness of sudden onset, with fever, chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion (redness without exudate), and myalgia. Muscle pain is intense and especially affects the calves, back, and abdomen.
  • The headache is intense, localized to the frontal or retroorbital region (resembling that occurring in dengue), and sometimes accompanied by photophobia.
  • Aseptic meningitis may be present and is more common among children than among adults.
  • Although Leptospira can be cultured from the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the early phase, the majority of cases follow a benign course with regard to the central nervous system; symptoms disappear within a few days but may persist for weeks.
  • Physical examination may include any of the following findings, none of which is pathognomonic for leptospirosis: fever, conjunctival suffusion, pharyngeal injection, muscle tenderness, lymphadenopathy, rash, meningismus, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly.
  • If present, the rash is often transient; may be macular, maculopapular, erythematous, or hemorrhagic (petechial or ecchymotic); and may be misdiagnosed as due to scrub typhus or viral infection.
  • Lung auscultation may reveal crackles.
  • Mild jaundice may be present
  • Fever with hepatorenal dysfunction hemorrhage, Calf tenderness is typical of leptospirosis. It is also called as Weil's disease caused by a bacteria called Leptospira. Symptoms of leptospirosis include high fever, red eyes, headache, muscle aches, abdominal pain.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, page number: 1417

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator for poor prognosis in a case of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
• The single most powerful predictor of survival is β2 microglobulin. It can substitute for staging.
  • S albumin and β2 microglobulin alone are used for staging Myeloma known as the International Staging System (ISS) and has replaced the Durie salmon staging.

INTERNATIONAL STAGING SYSTEM


  • 28% of patients present in stage I, 39% in stage II and 33% in stage III.
  • Other poor prognostic factors in myeloma are- High labelling index, circulating plasma cells, poor performance status and high LDH levels.
  • Chromosomal anomalies and Risk stratification:
  • No aneuploidy in karyotyping, t(11,14) and del 13 are associated with standard risk and a survival of 6-7 years.
  • Presence of any aneuploidy in karyotyping is associated with a high risk. Any other chromosomal anomaly than mentioned above is associated with high risk. 2-3year survival.
  • The ISS, when used along with the cytogenetic changes, forms the basis of the Revised ISS for staging.
  • Del 13 was previously thought to predict poor outcome, but now is not considered so due to the advent of newer agents.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition, page number: 872
